His tone and body language was clear that he was uncomfortable talking about it but they kept following up with more questions.  If your job is to meddle in people’s business, then you should be able to understand boundaries and know when you’re making the person uncomfortable. It’s called human decency.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm a poet and I write about grief, it doesn't mean I want to talk about this in interviews, my poems are my outlet just as Louis' songs are his creative outlet. What was offensive for fans, apart from seeing Louis upset, was the blandness and lack of originality of the questions. There is still so much they could have asked about the new album, which is NOT all about grief. How about asking Louis about his songwriting, I'd love to know more about that. The banal, leading, gossipy questions show the presenters probably did not listen to the whole album and that their "research" was second-hand at best. Louis is right to avoid such substandard presenters. I am a new fan by the way, and love his new album, which is really strong and the perfect bridge between 1D and Louis' new musical direction. I love his voice too and I'm looking forward to seeing him live in London next month.

snippet.textDisplay: I understand that, from the perspective of journalists, they see it as harmless. However, someone who has experienced loss - especially so close together - knows that there are lines you don't cross during interviews. They shouldn't have switched from trauma to Zayn to One Direction so quickly. And comparing it to Taylor Swift feels a bit too far. Taylor likes to keep what songs are about what boyfriends just to respect their personal lives as well as her own. Not talking about her relationships and not talking about her album are very different questions. You can ask why she chose playing the piano instead of the guitar in one of them, how it felt to be in a snowmobile crash and if she sustained injuries, or what song took her the longest to write. Those are still interesting questions that fans like. They could've asked about Louis seeing Niall at the show in Mexico instead of asking about Zayn. If they were talking about music when they brought up his grief, they should've kept going with other songs on his album instead of switching straight to Zayn.

snippet.textDisplay:
First of, the whole album is not about grief at all. The fact that we are able to get info about his personal life doesn't give us the right to ask him about it. Even if you are reporters. He has never ever talked about his sister's passing, ever and it hasn't even been 1 year before she tragically passed away. And they are directly referring to both of them passing, they asked about Two Of Us later. And, yeah, sure you can ask about a powerful song which means a lot to lots of people and he answered that question too many times but he still will answer 'cause he has acknowledged the fact and he knows what that song means for others.
About Zayn stuff, that was truly rude. He is there to promote his wonderful album, he is there to share that legacy with the world after 4 years of working and yeah, that would make him upset being asked about someone who's clearly unrelated to the situation. And One Direction thing, that has been asked a bunch of times and he always has been so honest and genuine about his point of view of the situation. So, over all, the fact that he was there to promote his album -which is not all about grief, he gets asked about things he doesn't want. I don't get why they are normalizing the situation. The fact that they didn't acknowledge what they did after Louis' tweet is whole other thing.
